thread.title: City hit with $11M verdict in discrimination suit
thread.title_full: City hit with $11M verdict in discrimination suit | Boston Herald

author: Brian Dowling
title: City hit with $11M verdict in discrimination suit
text:
City hit with $11M verdict in discrimination suit Jury awards Treasury Department worker Brian Dowling Saturday, October 24, 2015 City Hall comments Tweet A $70,000-a-year mid-level City Hall manager was awarded a nearly $11 million jury award for being discriminated against by a department head who repeatedly hired less-qualified people than her and retaliated when she filed a complaint.
Chantal Charles, a Haitian-American who works in the city’s treasury department, told the Herald she is “very pleased with the verdict” in the civil case.
“I like being a public servant. I love my job. I love what I do for a living,” she said, adding she hoped the city would promote worthy candidates of all races. “That’s the whole purpose of this.”
A jury in Suffolk Superior Court yesterday ordered the city to pay Charles $388,160 for economic damages, $500,000 for emotional distress, and a whopping $10 million in punitive damages.
“We understand that it is a large award, but it’s a signal from the jury that what the city has done deserves condemnation,” Charles’ attorney, Monica Shah, said.
Mayor Martin J. Walsh’s spokeswoman Laura Oggeri said the city will likely appeal the verdict and noted the alleged actions happened under the administration of the late Mayor Thomas M. Menino.
Charles started working for the city’s trust division in 1986, overseeing the Edward Ingersoll Browne Fund, which provides public art grants.
But in 1998, her division was transferred to the Treasury Department.
Over the next two years, Charles was stripped of her title as community services director even though she kept doing the same tasks, according to court documents.
Charles was never given an explanation for the changes and was denied a meeting with the city’s chief operating officer.
In 2011, her longtime boss retired after refusing a request by another city manager to give Charles a bad performance review, instead giving her positive marks, Shah said.
Charles took on her superior’s work without added pay or a promotion. But she was pushed further out of running the Browne fund, and she filed a complaint with the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination, court papers state.
While the complaint was being heard, the Treasury Department filled her old boss’ position, but changed the title and responsibilities so that Charles would not recognize the position, Shah said.
Meanwhile, two others were hired instead of Charles, and she was disciplined for the first time in her years working with the city.
